Its relevance to the reaction mechanism is discussed. It is now well known that palladium can be a good catalyst for the synthesis of methanol from CO H; or CO^-ii^ mixtures [1-4]. For ex- ample, Kikuzono et al. [5] have shown that starting from a MPdCl4 pre- cursor, a very selective catalyst could be obtained. However, questions re- main as to why the support is so important, and what is the reaction mechanism? The work of Poels et al. on Pd shows that both methane and methanol are possibly obtained through non-dissociatively adsorbed CO [3], and that there is a rather good correlation between the methanol activity and the concentration of Pd""1" species [6]. In our laboratory, we have performed chemical trapping with Pd + MgO/SiO^ catalytsts and found that a correla- tion exists between methanol activity at atmospheric pressure and the con- centration of formyi and methoxy surface species [7, 8]. We concluded that: the support is important because it can stabilize Pd in an oxidation state higher than zero ; a positive charge on Pd is necessary in order to favour the formation of formyi species, as shown in theoretical work by Anikin et al. [9]; formyi and methoxy groups are intermediates in the methanol forma- tion on palladium catalysts. Next, we proposed an adsorbed formaldehyde species as an inter- mediate between formyi and methoxy entities. Here we report experimental evidence for such adsorbed formaldehyde. The chemical trapping of species has been described elsewhere [10]. The catalysts were prepared and reduced as detailed in refs. 6 - 8. Hydrogen is evacuated after reduction, and the catalyst is contacted with CO or C02, CO + H; or COz + H;, at temperatures of 110 - 140 C. The trapping reagent (dimethyl sulfate DMS, diethyl sulfate DES, methanol MeOH) is then intro- duced at 110 C. 0304-5102/85/$3.30 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 134 TABLE 1 Chemical trapping experiments Catalysts Reagent Temperature Trapping Products" ( C) reagent 2%Pd/Si02 CO 140 MeOH CH2(OCH3)2 CO 110 MeOH CH^OCHah CO + 2H2 110 MeOH traces of CH2(OCH3)2 CO 110 EtOH CH2(OC2Hs)2 C02 130 MeOH CH2(OCH3)2 COi 130 DMS CH2(OCH3)2 C02 130 DES CH2(OC2Hs)2 COi + HI 130 MeOH CH2(OCH3)2 H2 110 MeOH "Detected amounts were -1-2x10 7 mol (g catalyst) 1. The products formed: formaldehyde dimethylacetal (MeOH, DMS) and formaldehyde diethylacetal (DES), are detected by gas chromatography. The results obtained are listed in Table 1. In the presence of excess hydrogen as well as on the more active 2%Pd- ;>c%MgO/Si02 catalysts, only trace amounts of adsorbed formaldehyde could be observed. The amount of formaldehyde is higher when only adsorbed hydrogen, and no gaseous hydrogen, is present. This may be due to the fact that in the presence of H; gas, or on the more active catalysts, the adsorbed formaldehyde can be quickly converted into the methoxy species and its remaining concentration on the catalytic surface is low. The presence of formaldehyde is in accordance with our proposed reac- tion mechanism : H H CHa \ \ / C=0 ?= H C-0 <== 0 H M M M Such a species adsorbed through both the carbon and the oxygen atoms has been observed in homogeneous catalysis [11,12]. For CO; + HI reaction, formyi and methoxy are also intermediates and formates have never been observed on Pd/SiO; [7, 8]. The formyi formation is puzzling in this last reaction, and can be explained in two ways: (a) insertion of CO; into the M H bond and a very fast transformation into a formyi entity, as in the experiments of Hattori and Wang [13]. H H C=0 ^C=0 M O M > M O M 135 (b) by direct hydrogenation of adsorbed C02, as shown by the works of Bowker et al. [14]. However, the presence of formaldehyde acetals could also be interpreted as an oxymethylene species. H H \^ 0^0 1 as proposed by He and Eckerdt [15] on ZrOa, but the absence of formates in our experiments inclines us to think that the first form is more probable. The formation of methanol by the intermediacy of an adsorbed formaldehyde can be limited to very low values (by the low thermodynamic stability of formaldehyde) if the rate-limiting step is the hydrogenation of this adsorbed species. However, Breault has observed on Rh Ce SiO; [16] catalysts that the presence of cerium widely enhances the rate of hydrogena- tion of aldehydes; such an enhancement could explain our results. The rate of aldehyde hydrogenation with various amounts of MgO is still under in- vestigation on our Pd MgO SiO^ catalyst. Acknowledgement We acknowledge the French GRECO-CO for financial support.
